The relocation of the capital from Damascus to Baghdad further centralized power under the Abbasids, fostering an environment conducive to intellectual and artistic pursuits.

In Western Europe, the coronation of Pepin III as emperor by Pope Zacharias in 751 AD was equally significant. This event exemplified the burgeoning power of the Carolingian kings and the growing influence of the papacy in matters of temporal rule, which would significantly reconfigure the political landscape of medieval Europe. By asserting his imperial status, Pepin III consolidated his hold over the Frankish kingdom and laid the groundwork for the future power of the Frankish emperors, including Charlemagne.
